header.title: Season of the Witch

collectionHeaderMetadata.description: Fighting a Stage-4 Carcinoma Diagnosis by Ted Rheingold
collectionHeaderMetadata.title: Season of the Witch

paragraphs.name: 776e
paragraphs.text: I’ve gained some powerful emotional powers (super powers) in what I’ve been calling my second life. Most all my deep-set hangups died with my first life. A number (but not all) of my grudges, entitled expectations, self-assumed responsibilities, judgements are simply gone. I have no FOMO. There isn’t an event I’ve heard of since I’ve recovered that I wish I would have been at. I’m simply content to be alive and living my. I have no bucket list. Life is the bucket.

paragraphs.name: 776e
paragraphs.text: I’ve gained some powerful emotional powers (super powers) in what I’ve been calling my second life. Most all my deep-set hangups died with my first life. A number (but not all) of my grudges, entitled expectations, self-assumed responsibilities, judgements are simply gone. I have no FOMO. There isn’t an event I’ve heard of since I’ve recovered that I wish I would have been at. I’m simply content to be alive and living my life. I have no bucket list. Life is the bucket.

I often pondered the philosophy of cancer because it’s hard to make sense of it. What’s the evolutionary benefit of killing your host when that kills you too? Why does cancer win to die? I was surprised to find so few results on Google. I asked my sister who has studied cancer for 20 years and she said it would be a good post for my blog. Cancer isn’t a virus or bateria. It’s a mutation. A mutation that happens with great regularity amongst some but not all mammals and it mutates in one of a recurring common or rare manners. What is cancer’s purpose. Is it to cull the herd? Is cancer non-evolutionary (i.e. not created by natural forces)? Is cancer still evolving? Is it’s end goal to become transferable from person to person? Tasmanian Devil populations have become decimated by a transferrable facial tumor disease. Are human cancers mutating in half of all humans for the chance to find the variant that leads to transferability? Will cancer jump the transferability firewall? What is the philosophy of cancer?
paragraphs.name: b37a

6c72f11c9363.title: I never know what to say, except if you need anything at any time, even if it’s just a novel face…

paragraphs.text: I never know what to say, except if you need anything at any time, even if it’s just a novel face for a coffee, let me know. It’s brilliant to have you doing so well and your writing is, as ever, extraordinary, honest and moving.

2d5ca341739f.title: I’m in awe of your grace, clarity, strength, and generosity through all of this, Ted.

14cda9438027.title: I’m on a train in Sydney, Australia trying to process your journey.

paragraphs.text: I’m on a train in Sydney, Australia trying to process your journey. Ted you’ve just reminded me and us of how resilient humanity can be. From one stranger to another at opposite ends of our planet, thank you!

paragraphs.text: Congratulations on your recovery.

paragraphs.text: My story is very different and yet similar. I came down with acute heart failure caused by pneumonia. I felt weak but that was it. 492079752716.title: May the rest of your life be long and happy!

paragraphs.text: May the rest of your life be long and happy! A stunningly courageous and beautifully written piece from a good man.
paragraphs.name: 825f

paragraphs.text: Could I just add, though, the hope that the drug that helped you so much can be made available to all who need it rather than only those who can pay its full cost? Should relative poverty be a death sentence?

paragraphs.name: 041b

paragraphs.text: Thank you for this. I agree that “life is the bucket.” I am a uterine cancer survivor. My up-close and personal appointment with mortality turned my carefully nursed decades-old grudges into will-o-the-wisps that disappeared in a flash. What a relief to find that those thoughts and feelings don’t matter in the grand scheme of my life!
paragraphs.name: 366e

d9394d9d6dfb.title: When I was diagnosed with leukemia and laying in the hospital bed undergoing chemo, I realized I…

paragraphs.text: When I was diagnosed with leukemia and laying in the hospital bed undergoing chemo, I realized I was thrust into another world, a rather large place most people prefer to ignore. The land of the sick.
paragraphs.name: de6c

paragraphs.text: I appreciate your very well written description of that place. That place where desperate hope and easy fear tries to survive…

paragraphs.text: Molly Ditmore saved my life. That was harder work than Marine boot camp and it came on just as fast. I’ll spend the rest of my life proving myself worthy.
paragraphs.name: 18ae

979aea87d3c3.title: We we diagnosed the same week last year.

paragraphs.text: We we diagnosed the same week last year. My son and I driving in an in between world space of dying tears and living wills from upstate NY to UPenn hospital for diagnostic confirmation and hopefully surgery. And I too am alive, through my son now knows where my ashes would have and may still be strewn. A ‘nuanced’ tumor was no match for the magically…

paragraphs.text: Tears. Molly. You climbed into her lap. More tears. Such a deep satisfaction from the telling of your resurrection. In. One. Year. Wow. (Liking the TShirt idea…)
paragraphs.name: b4e8

64ebb3ee40e1.title: I try to avoid cancer blogs.

paragraphs.text: I try to avoid cancer blogs. Why read about it when you’re living it. Ha ha. But seriously, it’s heartening to find others discovering positivity in something traditionally treated as all encompassingly awful. It’s awful, no mistake, but there is an upside, and you’ve summed it up beautifully. Thanks, and good luck with everything.
paragraphs.name: 4a68
